body.p: Back to the grammar main page.

section.title: What is consonant gradation?
section.p: When a word is conjugated, declined or derived, an alternation occurs in the consonants which are in the middle of the word. It is something like the English alteration in "wife" - "wives", but much more regular and productive:

ul.li: Mun liikon viehkat. (I like to run.)
Dás ledje ollu váttis sánit. (There were a lot of hard words in this.)
Dát lea váttis sátni. (This is a difficult word.)
Son lea hui sádnái. (He/She is extremely good with words).

section.title: Konsonantenes grader og stadier
section.p: The consonants that come between a syllable with strong stress and one with weak stress are called stem consonants. The Sami language has many different stem consonants, simple consonants, double consonants and consonant clusters. Consonant clusters consist of two or more different consonants. For example: lávu 'Lavvu [gen. sg.]', lávvu 'lavvu', lávdi 'sill; stage', lavdnji 'peat'.

Sami consonants can come in three quantitative grades or quantities: quantity I, quantity II and quantity III, which are represented here as: GI, GII and GIII, respectively. Simple consonants are GI. Double consonants and consonant clusters can represent both GII and GIII.

Usually GIII is said to be longer than GII. In the modern orthography it is impossible to see the difference between double consonants of quantity II and quantity III because both quantitative grades are represented orthographically with two letters: GIII: guossi 'guest', GII: guossit 'guests'. An exception to this is "-llj-", which is grade III, and "-lj-", which is grade II. Quantitative grade II consonant clusters can, of course, have more letters than grade III consonant clusters, and therefore appear as longer orthographic clusters: GIII: juolgi 'leg; foot', GII: juolggit 'legs; feet'.
Words undergo changes between two grades when they are inflected, namely a weak and a strong grade. Some inflectional forms take a strong grade, while others take a weak grade.

Quantity I always represents the weak grade when there is a variation between quantity I and quantity II, whereas quantity II represents the strong grade, e.g. máhtu - máđut 'worm - worms'. Quantity III always represents the strong degree, where quantity II is then weak grade, e.g. máhttu - máhtut 'skill - skills'.
Examples with strong grade on the left and weak grade on the right:

Some word stems can be attested in all three quantities, e.g. viegan 'I run', viehkat 'to run', viehkki 'runner'. Other word stems are only attested in two quantities, e.g. áddjá 'grandfather', ádjá 'grandfather [gen. sg.]'.

section.title: Consonant Gradation and Different Stem Types
section.p: Verbs, nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives are divided into three stem stypes, namely bisyllabic, trisyllabic and contracted stem types. Words are divided into thess groups according to consonant gradation and the number of syllables in the final foot.

A foot is a group of syllables where the first syllable has stress. sáme-giella 'the Sami language' and vil-bealli '[male] cousin' are compound words, both of which have two feet, despite the number of syllables. The word gonagas 'king', on the contrary, only has one foot.

Bisyllabic nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives have two syllables in the final foot. They are strong-grade in the nominative singular, illative singular and essive, and they are weak-grade in the plural, e.g. gussa - gusat 'cow - cows', vilbealli - vilbealit 'cousin - cousins [male]'.

Trisyllabic nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives have three syllables in the final foot in the plural, e.g. rieban - riebanat 'fox - foxes', nisu - nissonat 'woman - women'. The nominative singular and essive are weak-grade, the other forms are strong-grade, but not all trisyllabic nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives are subject to consonant gradation. Note that it is not the number of syllables in the singular that designates the stem type.

Contracted stem nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives have two syllable sin the final foot in both the singular and plural, just as in their bisyllabic counterparts. Consonant gradation, however, is like that found in trisyllabic nouns, numerals, pronouns and adjectives. They are weak-grade in the nominative singular and strong or extra strong-grade in the plural, e.g. boazu - bohccot 'reindeer - reindeer [nom. pl.]', bálggis - bálgát 'path - paths'. Note that the illative singular is strong-grade in all stem types.

Verbs are divided into the same stem types, but it is only bisyllabic verbs which undergo consonant gradation. They have two syllables in the final foot. In the present seven of the nine person forms are strong grade, with the first and second persons singular are weak-grade: Son čállá. (He/She writes.) Mun čálán. (I write.) Don čálát. (You[2sg.] write.) In the preterite, six persons are weak-grade, while the first and second persons singular and the third person plural are strong-grade, e.g. Son čálii. (He/She wrote.) Mun čállen. (I wrote.) Don čállet. (You wrote.) Sii čálle. (They wrote.) Note that the third person plural forms are always strong-grade. The connegation forms of the main verb are also weak-grade, e.g. Son ii 'čále'. (He/She doen't write.) Moai ean 'boađe'. (The two of us are not coming.)

section.title: Consonant Gradation Patterns
section.p: There are many consonant gradation patterns in Northern Sami. In the outline, below, all the patterns are divided into two parts, double consonant change in one and consonant cluster change in the other. Individual consonants can alternate with both double consonants and consonant clusers, and they are divided between the two groups..

Double consonants are subject to three types of alternation. They can alternate with individual consonants or identical double consonants. In the latter alternation the modern orthography does not lend itself to identifying a distinction. Double consonants can also alternate with other double consonants. In this situation, the strong grade is indicated with voiced consonants, and the weak grade with nonvoiced consonants. Examples are given with strong grade on the left and weak grade on the right:

Consonant clusters feature many alternations. The most common is that the final consonant of a cluster is doubled in the weak grade. Some clusters have additional alternations as well. In consonant clusters beginning in "-k-", the "-k-" alternates with "-v-" in the weak grade. Consonant clusters that begin with "-h-" have double consonants in quantity III, and they can also alternate with individual consonants. Here are some examples, with the strong grade on the left and the weak grade on the right:

In consonant clusters that consist of a plosive and a nasal stop, it is the plosive that alternates. In the strong grade we have a voiced plosive, and in the weak grade the plosive is nonvoiced. These consonant clusters can also alternate with individual consonants. Examples, with strong grade on the left and weak grade on the right:

These consonant clusters can be components of other consonants clusters, where they are preceded by another consonant. When this consonant is "-r-", the alternation remains the same, that is to say with regard to the voiced and voiceless plosives. When the cluster begins with other consonants, the nasal is lengthened to a double consonant in the weak grade, and the plosive disappears. Examples, with strong grade on the left and weak grade on the right:

ul.li: čorbmat - čorpman 'to hit with the fist'

section.title: Double Consonant Alternation
section.p: Double consonants alternate with individual consonants of the same type or identical double consonants. Note that combinations hll, llj, lj, nnj and hrr are double consonants, and not consonant clusters. At the same time hl, nj and hr are individual consonants.

tr.td: bulli - bullit 'swelling', ballat - balan 'to be afraid of'
orru, orrut, orun 'to be [in a state]'
rišša - riššat 'match', riššut - rišui 'to be in a rush'
muoŧŧái, muoŧŧa, muoŧat 'aunt [maternal, younger than mother]'

section.p: Double consonants can also alternate with double consonants of other double consonants. A good rule of thumb is that the voiced consonants represent strong grade, and the voiceless consonants represent weak grade. Note that ddj and dj are double consonants, and not consonant clusters. The voiceless sound dj can represent the strong pair when it alternates with the individual consonant j.

section.title: Consonant Cluster Alternations
section.p: Group 3: Consonant clusters beginning in "-h-", have a double consonant after "-h-" in quantity III, and an individual consonant after "-h-" in quantity II. GII can alternate with GIII, or with GI, which is an individual consonant.

tr.td: gihcci - gihci '(goat) kid', báhcit - bázán 'to remain'
Máhtte - Máhte 'Máhtte [name]', sihtat - siđan 'to want to'

section.p: Group 4: Consonant clusters that consist of one plosive and one nasal can alternate with individual consonants or with a similar consonant cluster. In GIII we have a voiced plosive, and in GII a voiceless plosive.

tr.td: eadni - eatnit 'mother', fitnan - finan 'to visit, to go somewhere'
boadnji - boatnjit 'husband', suotnjat - suonjan 'to crawl through/into'

section.p: Group 5: This group consists of plosive+nasal combination in compound with a preceding "-r-". There are only two grades; quantity III is the strong grade and quantity II is the weak grade. In the strong grade, we have a voiced plosive, and in the weak grade a voiceless plosive. In the strong grade you can hear glide vowel between the "-r-" and the consonant cluster: bárᵊdni 'boy'.

Group 6: This is the largest group of alternations. There are only two quantities, and they are quantity III as the strong grade, and quantity II as the weak grade. The last consonant in the strong grade is doubled in the weak grade. In the strong grade a glide vowel is pronounced between the first and second consonants, beađᵊbi 'shoulder blade'. In consonant clusters that begin with a nasal, "-i-", "-s-", "-š-", "-t-" or "-v-" there should not be any glide vowel, nor should there be a glide vowel in the consonant clusters "-ld-" or "-lt-". Below the groups are divided into tables according to the first letter.

tr.td: guđju - guđjjut 'cover for a man drawn sled/ ahkio'
gáisá - gáissát 'mountain with a snow cap'
boltut - bolttui 'to dig through, to quarry'

section.p: Group 7: Consonant combinations in this group have three or four letters in both quantity II and quantity III. In the strong grade we have a "-đ-", "-i-", "-l-" or "-v-" followed by a plosive+nasal combination. In the weak grade the nasal is doubled and the plosive disappears.

Group 8: This group consists of "-i-", "-n-", "-m-", "-r-" and "-v-" followed by "-s-" and "-š-" combinations. These clusters comply with the patterns that "-s-" and "-š-" compounds follow elsewhere, namely the last consonant in the strong grade is doubled when forming the weak grade.
Group 9: In this group we have consonant combinations that begin in "-k-" in the strong grade. In the weak grade the "-k-" alternates with "-v-", and the last consonant is doubled in length.
